Package de.hshl.obj.wavefront.obj

Class OBJDecoder

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.hshl.obj.wavefront.obj.OBJDecoder
  • public final class OBJDecoder
extends java.lang.Object
    The OBJDecoder collects predefined line parsers, which specify how each wavefront keyword should be interpreted. For example, the keyword "#" indicates that the rest of the line is a comment and should be ignored. On the other hand, the "v" keyword declares a three dimensional vertex position.

      • FACE_PARSER

        public static final Decoder.LineParser<PolygonalOBJBuilder> FACE_PARSER
        Parse a line strip by splitting every argument into its components where a slash was put, for example "0/1/2 1/2/3 2/3/4 ...". The first index is a position index, the second a texture coordinate index, and the third a surface normal index. Puts 0 as index where no index was specified.
        See Also:
        FAST_FACE_PARSER

      • FAST_FACE_PARSER

        public static final Decoder.LineParser<PolygonalOBJBuilder> FAST_FACE_PARSER
        Parse a line strip by splitting every argument into its components where a slash was put, for example "0/1/2 1/2/3 2/3/4 ...". The first index is a position index, the second a texture coordinate index, and the third a surface normal index. Puts 0 as index where no index was specified. This is an optimized version of FACE_PARSER. If any bugs are encountered, use that instead.

    • Method Detail

      • createDefaultPolygonalDecoder

        public static Decoder<PolygonalOBJBuilder> createDefaultPolygonalDecoder()
        Returns:
        This Decoder knows the OBJ syntax and will be able to parse OBJ data into any object implementing PolygonalOBJBuilder.

      • fastParseTripleVertexIndex

        public static VertexMultiIndex fastParseTripleVertexIndex​(java.lang.String string)
        Parameters:
        string - Examples: "2/2/1", "2", "3//", "6//4", "6/5/"
        Returns:
        Parse a triple vertex index consisting of a position, texture coordinate, and surface normal index separated by slash. If no slash is present, interpret the only integer as the position index. If no digits are separated by two slashes, the missing indices are 0.
